Hey guys, when creating a new CursorLoader is there a way to auto generate the projection String?
```new CursorLoader(
context,    
AppNameContract.Item.CONTENT_URI,
 new String[] {   // <--- This one here
       AppNameContract.Item.COLUMN_ID,
       AppNameContract.Item.COLUMN_1
       ... COLUMN_2
       [...]```
ehh
sugar orm would be one way but that means stop using sqlite directly
also <http://realm.io|realm.io>
but realm doesn’t use sqlite at all
you do get to map to and form pojo objects with those
that’s your best options that I know of, you can make some static String[] instances for common queries I guess
I think I'll just make a few static String[]s. :simple_smile:   Was hoping for kind an Android Studio right - click solution
yeah not really unfortunately
im actually giving a talk tonight about some of the different database options and why I choose realm for a project I just did
realm is far from perfect but gave me sql like interactions with almost no learning curve
I’m really looking forward to what realm and dbflow can become
if only realm solved some of it’s basic issues
but I think they got null solved, so at least something is moving
Any ideas to add a load more progress bar to a RecyclerView?
anyone tried sqlbrite?
i know that’s in beta right now
<@U0548MM6B>: I can’t come up with a valid reason to have null support anyways
hopefully they solved it by saying ‘dont ever store null, it’s a stupid idea'
its just like having @Nullable, I hate having to use it
but that is the way of java
you can’t always guarantee data is valid unfortunately :confused:
regardless, you should aim to never have null anything
you will have them but the less you have, the less bugs you will have
yeah, but I’d rather have my db not crash and burn if I a null happens :simple_smile:
it shouldn’t come to that
your data sources should be incapable of providing a null value
<@U055GGAHS|ian.shaun.thomas> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/ian.shaun.thomas/F07UY45DF/-.txt|Untitled> and commented: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Hoare>

file.name: -.txt
file.title: Untitled
file.preview: I call it my billion-dollar mistake. It was the invention of the null reference in 1965. At that time, I was designing the first comprehensive type system for references in an object oriented language (ALGOL W). My goal was to ensure that all use of references should be absolutely safe, with checking performed automatically by the compiler. But I couldn't resist the temptation to put in a null reference, simply because it was so easy to implement. This has led to innumerable errors, vulnerabilities, and system crashes, which have probably caused a billion dollars of pain and damage in the last forty years.
file.preview_highlight: I call it my billion-dollar mistake. It was the invention of the null reference in 1965. At that time, I was designing the first comprehensive type system for references in an object oriented language (ALGOL W). My goal was to ensure that all use of references should be absolutely safe, with checking performed automatically by the compiler. But I couldn't resist the temptation to put in a null reference, simply because it was so easy to implement. This has led to innumerable errors, vulnerabilities, and system crashes, which have probably caused a billion dollars of pain and damage in the last forty years.

text: :smile: damn his mistake
so that’s all im saying, I’m definitely not smarter than that guy or anyone else that has used null and fucked it up
so the best option I have is to never use null unless I have to
but yeah, I can’t always control the sources, especially if the backend dev decides he uses null values to indicate something
because im an idiot like everyone else and im going to screw it up
if your backend dev does that, you go tell them that is a bad design
throw errors, make the api return something else
don’t return null
the problem is usually I didn’t have a say in backend since most of clients I’ve worked for developed their own, especially the carriers who had some huge system that took a month to change a string
Yeah, that would never fly with me
now it’s ok, since the backend sits across my table
but now we don’t use any ORM or DB, just a bunch of singletons in the app :joy:
at least those should be testable =P
I use them frequently for that purpose, forcing isolation
and making sure it will be painful for anyone to come mess that up in the future
the answer when I asked the dude if he writes tests: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
<@U0542GLTE>: im not off my rocker right
you would agree returning null in an API is a bad idea right
About?
Uh. Yes

I would flip shit
one of the other major issues is debugging
what does null mean

text: inherently nothing, so did you give bad input, is the server broken, maybe it only works when other unrelated data is correct, maybe it wants something else, you have no idea
because its null
wondered that one too many times when I got response : null, yet sometimes it acted as “oh no, this user doesn’t have that tariff package activated for his number”, sometimes “oh our server is down"
That’s what response codes are for
People should learn how to use them
